attributes.title: Debias effects in a public administration context (Master Thesis)
attributes.description: This study examines the debias-literature in the context of public administration. Debias strategies are ‘techniques that undermines bias’ (Lilienfeld et al, 2009). For long, studies in the Public administration context have focused on documenting bias – eg. Negativity bias or motivated reasoning when processing performance information (Moynihan, 2018). This study aims to meet Donald Moynihan’s call for “using psychology to design ways to overcome biases and improve outcomes (Moynihan, 2018: 5)    This study asks whether citizen exposure to contextual debias-frame (comparing with experts) will reduce the effects of framed performance information when evaluating danish hospitals. Furthermore, we ask whether the debias effects last when exposed with a second framing of performance information. The study tests 1) debias-effects in the context of public administration 2) if the debias effects last over ‘time’.    In relation to the empirical tests, the study will elaborate a large theoretical overview of the debias-literature. This registration will primarily contain the empirical part of the study, which contains a survey experiment, and the empirical expectations in relation to this survey experiment.

q1.value: Debias effects in a public administration context (Master Thesis)

q3.value:
This study examines the debias strategies in the context of public administration. Debias strategies are ‘techniques that undermines bias’ (Lilienfeld et al, 2009). For long, public administration studies have focused on documenting bias – eg. negativity bias or motivated reasoning when processing performance information (Moynihan, 2008). This study aims to meet Donald Moynihan’s call for “using psychology to design ways to overcome biases and improve outcomes (Moynihan, 2018: 5)  

This study asks whether citizen exposure to contextual debias-frame (comparing with experts) will reduce the effects of framed performance information when evaluating danish hospitals. Furthermore, we ask whether the debias effects last when exposed with a second framing of performance information. The study tests 1) debias effects in the context of public administration 2) if the debias effects last over ‘time’.  

In relation to the empirical tests, the study will elaborate a large theoretical overview of the debias-literature. This registration will primarily contain the empirical part of the study, which contains a survey experiment, and the empirical expectations in relation to this survey experiment.

q4.value:
H1: no debias-frame (control group): we expect that individuals who get a “positive” performance information will have more positive evaluations of the public service than individuals who get a “negative” performance information.  

H2: Debias-frame (treatment group): we expect that an exposure to a debias-frame (comparing with expert knowledge) will reduce effects of both positive and negative framed performance information of the public service.  

H3: Debias-frame before negative framed performance information: we predict the debias effect to be stronger when exposed to negative performance information compared to positive performance information after exposure to debias-frame. We expect this because the debias effect should make individuals more sensitive and aware of bias. As individuals are more aware of negative information than positive information (Olsen, 2015), we will expect that the individuals with a debias-frame will be more aware of the negative frame and therefore more resistant to the frame.  

H4: Debias-frame over time: We predict the exposure to debias-frame will last and reduce effects of both positive and negative framed performance information.  

No studies have tested if contextual debias effects last over time. Therefore, we test this in a most likely case, where both performance-information concern danish hospitals. Therefore, we expect the debias-frame to last. Furthermore, the few studies that test cognitive debiasstrategies over time have been successful (Morewedge mfl. 2015; Olsen & Larsen, 2020).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
In this study, treatments consist of a debias-frame and framing of performance information. All respondents will be exposed to two experiment: (1) performance information on satisfaction with hospitals (2) performance information on hospital staff.  

Participants will be randomly assigned to 4 groups:  

1) Debias frame --> positive information --> experiment 2 (over time)  

2) Debias frame --> negative information --> experiment 2 (over time) 

3) No Debias frame --> positive information --> experiment 2 (over time) 

4) No Debias frame --> negative information --> experiment 2 (over time)

q9.value: The respondents will be automatically randomized to the above-mentioned groups trough the survey.  Furthermore, the order of the two equivalence-experiments will be randomized, to make sure that the order have no effect. That is if performance information 1 (satisfaction) was shown before or after performance information 2 (staff).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Our aim is to recruit a semi national representative sample of Danish residents through both the Epinion Panel and through Facebook, Twitter and other social networks

q13.value: We aim to have a sample between 1000 and 1500 participants. Our power calculations result in a minimum of 1550 respondents when we calculate for four groups. Due to power, we treat Experiment 2 as one test of debias over time, no matter the combination of equivalence framing (positive --> positive / positive --> negative / negative --> negative / negative --> positive).

question.value: Treatment variable:  Our treatment consists of a debias treatment (respondents answers will be told that their evaluations of Danish hospitals will be compared with expert evaluations) and two randomizations of performance equivalence framing on satisfaction (78% of the patients are satisfied vs. 22% of the patients are unsatisfied) and performance equivalence framing on staff (14 % of patients experience the staff as unfriendly vs. 86% of patients experience the staff as friendly).

Outcome variable:  an evaluation of the hospital on a scale from 0 to 10, where 10 is very good.

We also include 3 closed ended outcomes variables intending to capture the mechanism of the debias effect: During this survey, did you experience the following feelings 1) It was not necessary for me to be thorough with my answers  2) I feared that my answer would be incorrect 3) I felt that someone was watching me. The questions will be randomized in order, and asked on a scale of 5; much agreed to not at all agreed.  

Control variables: 
We also ask respondents whether they have been to the hospital within the last 12 months (personal experience) and if they currently – or previously have worked at a hospital (work-related experience) (Olsen, 2015).  

Other control variables include sex, age, education, employment status and region.

We plan to use OLS regression to test the differences between the treatment group and control group. We plan to use OLS regression to test whether the debias-treatment reduces/eliminate the expected relationship between the negative/positive performance information and the evaluation of the health sector. As both the debias-treatment and the performance information are dummy variables, the overall analysis will in reality be difference-in-means tests.  

In regard to H1, we expect that respondents who get a “negative” performance information (unsatisfied patients and unfriendly staff) will have a significantly lower evaluation of the Danish hospitals than respondents who get a “positive” performance information (satisfied patients and friendly staff).  

In regard to h2: We expect the debias frame to reduce the effects of both negative and positive equivalence framing on evaluations of the Danish hospitals. Thereby we expect that the evaluations of respondents exposed to the debias frame will be more similar. If the bias effects are eliminated by the debias-treatment, there will no longer be a significant relationship between equivalence framing and evaluations of the Danish hospitals.

In regard to H4, we create two experiments in a row. We make a most likely case without any questions in between the two experiments. As it is a most likely test, we expect that the exposure of the debias-treatment will last in both experiments, and therefore reduce effects of equivalence framed performance information in both experiment 1 and experiment 2.  

In the main analysis we will treat 4 experimental groups. The main focus is to compare respondents exposed to debias-frame with respondents not exposed to debias-frame. Furthermore, our focus is to test the effects of debias “over time” with the second experiment: The evaluations in experiment 2 will be compared between respondents exposed to debias-frame with respondents not exposed to the debias-frame – no matter the combination of equivalence framing between the two experiments. (e.g. positive framing - negative framing, positive – positive etc.).  

The combination and order of equivalence frame are important, but it is not our main interest. This will be a part of our robustness test instead. The combination and order can have implications for power if we have to divide respondents in either 8 groups (combination of equivalence framing) or 16 groups (order of the two experiments), when performing these analyses. We choose to include dummy variables on order and combinations in our robustness check regressions.  


Robustness test 

1) Does the order of the two experiments have a significant effect on debias-frame effect? We will create a dummy variable that indicate the order (1 = performance information 1 first, 0 = performance information 2 first) 

2) Counter framing: respondents who are exposed to a positive frame in the first experiment and then a negative frame in the second experiment, might “figure out” the equivalence. The respondents will then make a higher evaluation in the second experiment (Druckmann,2001; Olsen, 2015). We will make an analysis without this group to check whether the counter framing effect migth be the reason for a significant debias-effect.

q25.value:
The debias frame is our main contribution and therefore we have choosen to replicate the study of Olsen 2015 (Equivalence framing study). Thereby our study aims to test, if it is possible to reduce equivalence framing with a debias strategies. Naturally we chose to replicate a study, where effects of equivalence are present  (Equivalence framing creates negativity bias and positivity bias). Thereby making sure that the bias is (or should be) present and thereby possible to debias (Fazio, 1990).

Literature cited: 
Fazio, Russell H. 1990. “Multiple Processes by Which Attitudes Guide Behavior: The Mode Model as an Integrative Framework”. I Advances in Experimental Social Psychology, Elsevier, 75–109. 

Fischhoff, Baruch. 1982. “For Those Condemned to Study the Past: Heuristics and Biases in Hindsight”. I Judgment under Uncertainty, red. Daniel Kahneman, Paul Slovic, og Amos Tversky. Cambridge University Press, 335–52

Kahneman, Daniel, Paul Slovic, og Amos Tversky. 1982. Judgment under Uncertainty: Heuristics and Biases. Cambridge: University Press. 

Larsen, Martin Vinæs, og Asmus Leth Olsen. 2020. “Reducing Bias in Citizens’ Perception of Crime Rates: Evidence From a Field Experiment on Burglary Prevalence.” Journal of Politics, 82(2). https://martinvinaes.github.io/martinvinaes.github.io/papers/LarsenOlsenJOP.pdf (13. februar 2020).

Lilienfeld, Scott O., Rachel Ammirati, og Kristin Landfield. 2009. “Giving Debiasing Away: Can Psychological Research on Correcting Cognitive Errors Promote Human Welfare?” Perspectives on Psychological Science 4(4): 390–98. 

Morewedge, Carey K. m.fl. 2015. “Debiasing Decisions: Improved Decision Making With a Single Training Intervention”. Policy Insights from the Behavioral and Brain Sciences 2(1): 129–40. 

Moynihan, Donald. 2018. “A Great Schism Approaching? Towards a Micro and Macro Public Administration”. Journal of Behavioral Public Administration 1(1). https://www.journal-bpa.org/index.php/jbpa/article/view/15 (7. februar 2020). 

Olsen, Asmus Leth. 2015a. “Citizen (Dis)Satisfaction: An Experimental Equivalence Framing Study”. Public Administration Review 75(3): 469–78.

attributes.title: TRANSITS- Work to Retirement Transition Project
attributes.description: Study about the life to retirement transition of different worldwide populations.

summary.value: This registration is being done before the manuscript is sent for consideration to a scientific journal. The project was already included in OSF one year ago with the name: TRANSITS work to retirement research project.

attributes.title: Perceiving economic inequality in everyday life decreases tolerance to inequality

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: A pilot study to assess construct validity

sample.value: To detect an effect of.30 (with one tail, a power of .80 and an alpha of .05), 278 participants are needed. Data will be collected from 300 participants to ensure the number needed for adequate power.

analyses.value:
H1. A t-test for independent samples with the PEIEL’s scale as the dependent variable and PEIEL’s manipulation as the independent variable. 
H2. A t-test for independent samples with the perception of economic differences as the dependent variable and PEIEL’s manipulation as the independent variable.

outliers.value:
Outliers
Outliers will be excluded when there are three or more typical deviations away from the mean of any dependent variable.

Exclusions 
We will exclude participants who did not write what they were asked for during the manipulation (they will be excluded before analyzing the data) and not Spanish population.

dependent.value:
Perception of Economic Inequality in Everyday Life (PEIEL)’ scale: a 12-item Likert scale with a 7-point response format ranging from 1 (completely disagree) to 7 (completely agree). A higher score means participants perceive more economic inequality in their daily lives (García-Castro, Willis, & Rodríguez-Bailón, 2019). 
Perception of economic differences: how many economic differences are there between the people you described at the beginning? A Likert scale from 1 (no difference) to 7 (many differences). 
Other variables being measured 
Sociodemographics: Sex and age.

conditions.value:
The experiment is between participants:
-Manipulation of Perceived Economic Inequality in Daily Life: Please think about the person you personally know who has the most economic resources and the person you personally know who has the least economic resources. Describe what they can do and what not with the resources they have. Tell us how economic resources influence their lives by writing at least one paragraph for each of these two people. Please do not tell us what are their personal attributes or characteristics; we are particularly interested in how economic resources influence their lives.
-Control condition: Please think about the person of the smallest height you personally know and the tallest person you personally know. Think about what they can do and what not with their height. Tell us how their height influences their lives by writing at least one paragraph for each of these two people.  Please do not tell us what are their personal attributes or characteristics; we are particularly interested in how their height influences their lives.

hypothesis.value:
The present study aims to make a pilot test of the Perception of Economic Inequality in Everyday Life (PEIEL)’s manipulation to know its construct validity. Then the hypotheses are:
1.	Participants assigned to the High Perceived Economic Inequality in Everyday Life condition will show a higher score in the PEIEL’s scale compared to those assigned to the control condition.
2.	Participants assigned to the High Perceived Economic Inequality in Everyday Life condition will show a higher score in the perception of economic differences compared to those assigned to the control condition.

attributes.title: MRI neuroimaging techniques in assessing the effects of alcohol consumption and heavy episodic drinking on the adolescent brain: a scoping review
attributes.description: The use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) including structural MRI (sMRI) (brain volume), functional MRI (fMRI) (functional activation), diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) (microstructural volume), and susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) techniques (cerebral microbleeds) in evaluating the effects of alcohol use and heavy episodic drinking on the adolescent brain.

q1.value: The use of MRI neuroimaging techniques in assessing the effects of alcohol consumption and heavy episodic drinking on the adolescent brain: a scoping review

q2.value: nancy hornsby, bronwyn myers, Soraya Seedat, eric westman, lars-olof wahlund

q3.value: The use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) including structural MRI (sMRI) (brain volume), functional MRI (fMRI) (functional activation), diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) (microstructural volume), and susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) techniques (cerebral microbleeds) in evaluating the effects of alcohol use and heavy episodic drinking on the adolescent brain.

q4.value: Qualitative review; no intervention therefore no hypotheses

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a scoping review for critical appraisal of MRI neuroimaging techniques in evaluating the effects of alcohol use and heavy episodic drinking on the adolescent brain. This review will involve a qualitative phenomenon of interest i.e., MRI techniques. Adolescent drinkers (males and females) aged 13 to 18 years. The outcomes of interest are:
- Brain region volume measured in brain voxels (millimeters (mm) for sMRI and micrometers (µm) for DTI data).
- Percentage (%) blood oxygenated level-dependent (BOLD) signal change in brain activation.
- Cerebral microbleeds (CMBs) measured in brain voxels (mm).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The scoping review will be conducted following the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses [PRISMA] (169) (Appendix 22). An English-only search will be conducted of published literature across six databases including Medline (Ovid), PsycInfo (Ovid), Embase (Elsevier), CINAHL (Ebsco), Web of Science (Thomson Reuters) and Cochrane (Wiley). The search will be limited to English studies published between 1999 to 2019.

- Brain region volume measured in brain voxels (millimeters (mm) for sMRI and micrometers (µm) for DTI data).
- Percentage (%) blood oxygenated level-dependent (BOLD) signal change in brain activation.
- Cerebral microbleeds (CMBs) measured in brain voxels (mm).
Qualitative synthesis of findings

q22.value: criteria will include: (i) individuals younger than 13 years and older than 18 years and; (ii) case studies, reviews, theses, letters to editors, editorials, commentaries, and conference abstracts.

- Percentage (%) blood oxygenated level-dependent (BOLD) signal change in brain activation.
- Cerebral microbleeds (CMBs) measured in brain voxels (mm).

An English-only search will be conducted of published literature across six databases including Medline (Ovid), PsycInfo (Ovid), Embase (Elsevier), CINAHL (Ebsco), Web of Science (Thomson Reuters) and Cochrane (Wiley). The search will be limited to English studies published between 1999 to 2019.

attributes.title: Computer-based intervention for supporting individuals in changing negative thinking patterns

q1.value: Computer-based intervention for supporting individuals in changing negative thinking patterns

q3.value: Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) aims at replacing negative thinking patterns with healthier ones. This process, however, typically requires great effort; a person can believe in new thoughts but still feel that these thoughts are not as applicable to their lifestyle or experiences as the old (negative) thoughts. However, therapists often struggle with patients’ homework compliance. Therefore, training and strengthening the newly formed thoughts is an important aspect of CBT, as it helps enforce the new thoughts in one's mind. This study aims at evaluating a prototype of a conversational agent intervention for motivating individuals to perform thought strengthening exercises. This research is done within the context of a master's thesis.

q4.value:
H1- The users' perceived usefulness of the thought-strengthening exercises is highest in the conversational agent support case, followed by the text support case and then the no support case.

H2- The users' self-efficacy toward the thought-strengthening exercises is highest in the conversational agent support case, followed by the text support case and then the no support case.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The experiment will have a mixed design and include three groups: Group A will receive the intervention only (i.e., the exercises to strengthen a new thought); Group B will get the intervention and support strategies to address motivational barriers, but they will not be delivered by a chatbot; and Group C will receive the intervention and support strategies delivered by a chatbot. The participants will be randomly assigned to the groups. The participants of each group will be asked to fill pre- and post-experiment surveys on the measures (namely, perceived usefulness and self-efficacy) that will be used to compare the three groups.

q9.value: The participants will be randomly assigned by the computer to one of the three equally sized groups. Also, the participants will randomly receive one of two scenarios to perform the exercise with.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The experiment will be conducted online and will include 4 phases. The first phase will be the introduction, in which the participants will be asked to complete an informed consent form. Additionally, they will be briefed about the nature of the experiment and informed about the exclusion policies for responses (e.g., if they write gibberish or irrelevant answers). Before the experiment, the participants will be shown an example of how to complete a cognitive therapy exercise using an artificial scenario. This will be followed by comprehension check questions. In phase 2, they will be asked to fill out a pre-questionnaire, which will be hosted on Qualtrics. The questionnaire will cover three main parts: a perceived usefulness subscale, which is derived from the Intrinsic Motivation Inventory (McAuley et al. 1989); a self-efficacy questionnaire, which is based on participants' self-image with regard to doing the thought-strengthening exercises; and a question asking to distribute 20 minutes on two tasks: picture identification task and thought strengthening exercise. Afterward, they will be presented with three motivational barriers that could obstruct them from completing the thought strengthening exercise and they will be asked to rank them based on how applicable they are to themselves. We will have three barriers in the experiment: usefulness, self-efficacy, and perfectionism. The participants will then be given a new, randomly selected scenario and asked to rate the believability of 3 negative and 3 positive thought options from 0 to 100 percent. The highest-rated (negative and positive) thoughts will be used in the exercise. The third phase is the experiment itself, wherein Groups B and C will receive support corresponding to each participant’s top motivational barrier, while Group A will receive nothing. In the beginning, the participants will write evidence for or against their most believable negative thought to examine it, then write evidence for the most believable positive thought. After that, they will be asked again to rate the believability of the 3 negative and 3 positive thoughts (from 1 to 100 percent). In the last phase, the intervention’s effect on the participants’ behavioral intentions will be assessed by asking them to rerate the barrier, having them answer the questionnaire again, and asking them the picture identification question again. An additional survey will be added regarding their enjoyment of the barrier addressing method, and this survey will be derived from the Intrinsic Motivation Inventory (McAuley et al. 1989).

The participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk, and the workers should be from English-speaking countries. Each worker will be paid $3.50 each after completing the experiment.

q13.value: We aim to have at least 153 participants in our sample (51 in each group). However, we will attempt to recruit 189 participants (63 in each group) in case there is missing data.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis using G*Power. We based it on the difference between two independent means t-tests to obtain a medium effect size of 0.5 with a power of 0.80 and a 0.05 error probability. However, this is repeated three times as we need to compare the three groups with each other (Groups A and B, Groups B and C and Groups A and C). This may give a sample size that is higher than we actually require.

q15.value: Due to financial constraints, recruitment will stop after we gather data from 189 participants. The experiment’s budget is $661.5.

question.value:
Variable: Presentation format of motivational strategies.
Three levels: none, textual and chatbot.

To test the hypothesis, we will need to measure the participants’ perceived usefulness of and self-efficacy toward the thought-strengthening exercises. Therefore, usefulness will be measured through a version of the usefulness subscale (six questions) derived from the Intrinsic Motivation Inventory (McAuley et al. 1989). The self-efficacy questionnaire will be measured using five items adopted from Ding, D. et al. (2017), Hopp, T., & Gangadharbatla, H. (2016), Qu, C. et al. (2015) and Kang, N. (2016). All four studies followed Bandura’s (2006) approach to produce their self-efficacy assessments.
As the experiment has a mixed design with pre- and post-measures, we will take the delta of the measures and compare it to the other conditions. The usefulness survey will record participants’ answers using a 7-point Likert scale. On the other hand, the self-efficacy survey will be evaluated using a 10-point Likert scale, based on the suggestion by Bandura (2006).

The mean of the six questions in the usefulness survey will be taken to obtain a measure of perceived usefulness. The same will be done with the five items in the self-efficacy survey, which will produce a measure of self-efficacy.

We will test the reliability of the items with an alpha level of 0.65, based on the suggestion by Loewenthal, K. (2001). If they are correlated, they will be included in one indicator. Otherwise, we will remove the items that affect the correlation negatively. Dropping these items could improve the reliability to the desired acceptable level (0.65), which would allow us to continue the analysis.

We will use a multivariate multilevel model, wherein as a random effect, we will use participant numbers and as fixed effects, we will use the pre- and post-experiment surveys and the two conditions in the hypotheses (self-efficacy and usefulness).
The analysis will be done in two steps: First, we will use an omnibus test to perform an overall analysis in order to uncover the general differences between the three groups. The second step is to do a detailed analysis of the two conditions mentioned in the hypotheses (self-efficacy and perceived usefulness). 
For the model, we will have a random intercept and a fixed slope, as we are assuming that all participants have the same direction but with various starting points.

q21.value: We will use p-value less than 0.05 as a cutoff for significance.

q22.value:
There will be a comprehension check after the example video is shown. Those who do not answer the questions correctly will be unable to continue the experiment. Participants who write nonsensical answers to the task questions (unrelated answers or words without meaning) will be excluded from the study. The same applies if the thought ratings are all the same, or if the participants spend less than 30 seconds in registering the thoughts believability.

In addition, if a participant registers 0 for the applicability of all three pre-barriers, then their answers will be excluded from the experiment. This is mainly because 0 represents the minimum applicability of a motivational barrier, which means the barrier cannot be rated less in the post-question.

q23.value: There will not be missing data as the participants will not be able to continue unless they fill out all of the fields.

q24.value:
In the exploratory analysis, we will look at three additional conditions: enjoyments, engagement and barrier believability:

Enjoyment:
This is defined by the participants’ enjoyment of overcoming the barrier during the experiment. The enjoyment will be compared between two groups: the group that receives the support chatbot and the group that receives the text support. This is because it is related to their enjoyment of the barrier-overcoming method, which the third group will not receive. To measure this, we will use only a post-experiment questionnaire (7 questions), derived from the Intrinsic Motivation Inventory (McAuley et al. 1989). Also, an alternative measure would be by asking the participant the picture identification question before and after doing the exercise. We will use the same test and model as before, however, without the fixed effect in the case of the questionnaire (as it is only a post-experiment questionnaire).  

Engagement:
This is defined by the participants’ engagement with the webpage. This will be measured in two ways: active writing time and the number of written arguments in their answers. Active writing time will be determined based on the time the participant spends interacting with the argument-writing exercise. If the participant is not interacting with the exercise tab or not doing any activity (mouse movements, keyboard clicks, etc.) for 15 consecutive seconds, the timer will pause until he or she interacts again. These are only post-experiment measures. 

Change in thought believability:
We will ask the participants to rate the negative and positive thought believability before and after doing the arguments writing exercise. We will take the delta of the thoughts, and it will be tested using the same method as before.

Change in barrier:
To see if the barrier overcoming method works, the participants will be asked about the barriers before and after doing the exercise. This will be tested using the same method as before and will be based on the percentage the participants assign them with regard to how applicable they think they are (0-100).

attributes.title: Parental warmth moderating the association between exposure to emotional abuse from a romantic partner and perceived burdensomeness

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Associations between parental warmth, exposure to emotional/verbal abuse in romantic relationships, and perceived burdensomeness

other.value: Other variables that are collected for exploratory purposes are additional demographics factors - age, marital status, gender, employment, relationship status, birth order and the number of siblings.

sample.value: The target sample size for the current study is 212 participants. Achieving this sample will ensure a reasonable level of precision, given that we expect to observe correlations between the study's key variables (parental warmth, frequency of exposure to emotional/verbal abuse from a romantic partner, and perceived burdensomeness) around r =.30 (Schonbrodt & Perugini, 2013).

analyses.value:
The analysis for the current research study consists of two parts. 
1: The first step includes calculating the correlations between the variables. (Parental Warmth, Emotional Abuse, and Perceived Burdensomeness). We expect negative associations between warmth and exposure to emotional/verbal abuse in romantic relationships, a negative association between warmth and perceived burdensomeness,  and a positive association between exposure to emotional/verbal abuse in romantic relationships and perceived burdensomeness.
2: The second step involves performing multiple regression, with age, gender, perceived parental income, parental warmth scores, exposure to emotional/verbal abuse from a romantic partner, and the interaction between these latter two variables entered as predictor variables. If the interaction term is a significant predictor of perceived burdensomeness, this will be evidence for the predicted moderating effect. This moderating effect will be further explored using the 'medmod' package in Jamovi.

outliers.value: Any participants who respond to fewer than 75% of the items of any of the study variables will be excluded from the analysis.

dependent.value:
For the current research study, the dependent variable is Perceived Burdensomeness (assessed via the Burden subscale of the Interpersonal Needs Questionnaire; van Orden et al., 2012).
 
The independent variables are parental warmth (assessed via the maternal and paternal care subscales of the Parental Bonding Inventory; Parker et al., 1979). and exposure to emotional/verbal abuse from a romantic partner (assessed via a revised version of the Restrictive Engulfment and the Denigration subscales of the Multidimensional Measure of Emotional Abuse (Murphy & Hoover, 1999).

hypothesis.value: We will test whether low parental warmth moderates the link between exposure to emotional/verbal abuse from a romantic partner and perceived burdensomeness. Participants who report low levels of warmth and exposure to more frequent emotional/verbal abuse are expected to report the highest levels of burdensomeness.

attributes.title: Feeling Authentic: What is the Source?

q1.value: Feeling Authentic: What is the Source?

q3.value:
Research Question 1:
What makes us feel authentic? Theories of authenticity suggest that people should feel most authentic when they act in line with the unique pattern of qualities that make up their true self, that is, what makes them really them (Harter, 2002; Kernis & Goldman, 2006; Schmader & Sedikides, 2018). However, daily diary studies consistently find that people feel most authentic when their behavior conforms to a particular pattern of personality traits (e.g., high extraversion, high agreeableness, high conscientiousness, low neuroticism, and high openness) rather than acting in line with their own patterns of baseline traits (see Beer & Harris, 2019 for a review).  
Why would this pattern of personality traits make people feel more authentic than the pattern of qualities they claim characterizes their true self? One possibility is suggested by the way we judge authenticity in objects. Specifically, people tend to judge the authenticity of food or other objects based on their conformity to convention (Lehman, O’Connor, Kovacs & Newman, 2018). The pattern of qualities that tend to be associated with feelings of authenticity in daily diary studies tend to be those that are valued by the participants’ societies (most studies have been conducted in Western countries). Research has shown that we view people as less than fully human when they fail to conform to societal conventions (Fincher & Tetlock, 2016). Therefore, when it comes time to make a judgment about our own authenticity, we may use criteria that are closer to how we judge the authenticity of an object such as food. It may be that we draw on social conventions about how a person should act to evaluate our own authenticity.
Therefore, we will test the extent to which feelings of authenticity are increased by thinking about what it means to be a human (e.g., “What is it about you that makes you human”), the true self (e.g., “What is it about you that makes you who you really are?”), or a control condition in which self-evaluation is grounded in a day’s activity (e.g., “What kind of activities are you doing today?”).

Question 1: Does priming someone to think about their humanity (general category) vs. their true self (unique to them) affect feelings of authenticity?

Research Question 2:
How much do people value learning about their “true self” compared to other kinds of self-relevant information?  Research on authenticity asserts that people strive to know their true selves (Harter, 2002; Kernis & Goldman, 2006; Schmader & Sedikides, 2018). In addition to research on authenticity and self-assessment, there is a large literature discussing people’s interest in self-enhancement (Alicke & Sedikides, 2011; Sherman & Hartson, 2011) and self-verification (Swann, 1983, 1990). However, there is less empirical evidence concerning how much people relatively place value on learning about their true, core selves in relation to self-enhancing and self-verifying information. This research tests how much people value feedback about their true self compared to self-verifying (confirming what you already know) or self-enhancing (only revealing your strengths) feedback. Our previous research has suggested that participants, when asked in a between-subject design, tend to value feedback about their true self more than self-verifying feedback (and self-enhancing feedback falls in between). In this study, we use a within-subject design to understand more explicit representations of value across these feedback types. That is, when people are aware that these various types of feedback are available, do they self-report placing more value on feedback about their true selves than self-verifying feedback (with self-enhancing feedback’s value falling in between the two) or do they show a different pattern of value? Specifically, we will measure  willingness to pay (WTP) for personality information as a function of the framing of the feedback as 1) revealing the true, core self, 2) confirming their preexisting self-conceptions, 3) as only self-enhancing in nature, or 4) not specified (control condition in which no details about the feedback are specified).

Question 2: Does an individual’s willingness to pay for personality information differ as a function of the framing of the feedback they will receive?

Exploratory Research Questions:
Question 3: We plan to explore the effect of the writing prompt manipulation on subcomponents of authenticity (rather than an aggregate score). We will conduct a parallel analyses as those described under “statistical models” for the four subscales of our Authenticity measure (unbiased processing, relational orientation, awareness, and behavior)

Question 4: We will test for correlations between Authenticity, the four subscales of Authenticity (awareness, unbiased processing, behavior, and relational orientation), Self-esteem, Meaning in Life, each factor of the BFI (openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism), and willingness to pay.

Question 5: We plan to explore the effect of the writing prompt manipulation on our meaning in life measure (both subscales, presence and search; Schlegel, Hicks, King & Arndt, 2011).

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: We hypothesize that there will be a main effect of writing prompt (humanity, authenticity and control) on feelings of authenticity. Theories of authenticity from the self literature suggest that thinking about one’s true self would significantly increase feelings of authenticity beyond simply recounting one’s daily activities (H1a) whereas theories about authenticity from the consumer goods literature suggests that thinking about what makes someone human should additionally significantly increase feelings of authenticity beyond simply recounting one’s daily activities (H1b).  

Hypothesis 2: We hypothesize that there will be a main effect of feedback type on willingness to pay. If people’s explicit representations of the value of self-relevant feedback are similar to their tacit representations (measured in our previous work), then it may be that people will pay more for feedback about their true self than self-verifying or control condition feedback while self-enhancing feedback will fall in between the true self and self-verifying conditions (i.e., not significantly different from either).

question.value:
Overview: Participants complete a writing task as well as questionnaires assessing authenticity, meaning in life, self-esteem, the Big Five, and the value of different types of personality feedback. After completing a series of personality measures outlined in “measured variables” and assessing two TAT pictures (not measured but included to increase the ostensible validity and sophistication of the testing to participants), participants indicate their willingness to pay for four different types of personality reports offering different types of feedback (self-enhancing, self-verifying, true self, and control). They will then answer a series of demographic questions and view the debriefing form. 

To address question 1, we use a between-subjects design with writing prompt (humanity, authenticity, and control) as a between-subjects factor. The dependent variable is Authenticity (composite score from the Kernis-Goldman Authenticity Inventory – Short Form). 

To address question 2, we use a within-subjects design where subjects are exposed to all four feedback types and measure the subjects’ willingness to pay for each type of feedback with a set amount of money ($20).

Procedure:
1. Self-Reference Writing Task. Participants will be instructed to write for 2 minutes on one of three prompts:
	A. Human Convention condition: “What is about you that makes you human?”
	B. True self condition: “What is it about you that makes you who you really are?”
	C. Control condition: “What kind of activities are you doing today?”

2. Questionnaires. Participants will be instructed to complete the following questionnaires ostensibly to develop a personality profile. We randomly present our target Authenticity items with items from other personality questionnaires.
A. Kernis-Goldman Authenticity Inventory – Short Form (KGAI-SF; 20 items): Participants will complete this inventory to measure a composite authenticity score as well as four subscales, 1) awareness, 2) unbiased processing, 3) behavior, and 4) relational orientation, (1 – disagree strongly, 5 – agree strongly)
B. Big Five Inventory (BFI; 44 items): Participants will complete this inventory to measure the Big Five Factors (dimensions) of personality, (1 – disagree strongly, 5 – agree strongly).
C. Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE; 10 items): Participants will complete this inventory to measure global self-worth, (1 – disagree strongly, 5 – agree strongly)
D. Meaning in Life Questionnaire (MLQ; 10 items): Participants will complete this inventory to measure two dimensions of meaning in life: 1) presence of meaning and 2) search for meaning, (1 – absolutely untrue, 5 absolutely true)

3. Value of Personality Feedback Task. Participants will be instructed to allocate $20 to reflect how much they would be willing to pay for the four different types of feedback displayed below. They have the option to allocate similar or different amounts across feedback type but allocations must add up to $20.
A. Self-enhancement condition: “Cross validation studies conducted by the University of Michigan in collaboration with the University of California, Los Angeles have shown that feedback from this set of personality tests identifies positive personal qualities you may not already know about yourself.” 
B. Self-verification condition: “Cross validation studies conducted by the University of Michigan in collaboration with the University of California, Los Angeles have shown that feedback from this set of personality tests confirms personal qualities that you are likely to already know about yourself.”
C. True self condition: “Cross validation studies conducted by the University of Michigan in collaboration with the University of California, Los Angeles have shown that feedback from this set of personality tests identifies who you truly are, both positive and negative personal qualities.”
D. Control condition: “Cross validation studies conducted by the University of Michigan in collaboration with the University of California, Los Angeles have been conducted on this set of personality tests [no other details about feedback are specified].”

4. Demographic Information.
A. Difficulty: “How difficult is it to know your true self?” (1 – not difficult at all, 5 – very difficult)
B. Existence of true self: “The true self is real” (1 – strongly disagree, 5 – agree strongly)
C. Demographic variables: Participants will report their age, gender, and ethnicity/race

5. Debriefing. Participants are debriefed on the purpose of the study.

question.value:
1) Self-reference prompt: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions: human convention, true self, and control. Wording for each prompt type is listed in the procedure above.

2) Feedback type: Participants are presented with all four conditions specifying the feedback type that the personality report could provide: self-enhancement, self-verification, true self, and control. Wording for each feedback type is listed in the procedure above.

Authenticity: Kernis-Goldman Authenticity Inventory Short Form-20; we will compute composite trait authenticity scores as well the four subscales of awareness, unbiased processing, behavior, and relational orientation.

Personality Dimensions: Big Five Inventory; we will compute scores for openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism

Meaning in Life: Meaning in Life Questionnaire (MLQ; 10 items); we will compute two dimensions of meaning in life: 1) presence of meaning and 2) search for meaning

Self-esteem: Rosenberg Self-esteem scale; we will compute a composite score for global self-esteem.

Willingness to pay: After viewing the four types of personality feedback (outlined in procedure), participants will be asked to allocate their $20 across the feedback to indicate how much they would be willing to pay for each type of personality report.

Gender: What is your gender? (Male, female, I prefer not to answer, other)

Age: What is your age? (text entry)

Race: Choose one or more races that you consider yourself to be: (White, Black or African American, American Indian or Alaska Native, Asian, Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander, Latinx/Hispanic, other)

In all scales, negatively framed items will be reverse scored. Negatively framed items are marked with an (R) in the attached materials (FAWS - Measures.docx). Composite scores will be computed for each of the scales in addition to subscale scores when possible. For the Kernis-Goldman Authenticity Inventory – Short Form, a composite authenticity score will be computed as well as scores for all four subscales, 1) awareness, 2) unbiased processing, 3) behavior, and 4) relational orientation. For the BFI, a score will be computed for openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism. For self-esteem, a single composite score will be computed. For the Meaning in Life Questionnaire, a score will be computed for the presence of meaning and the search for meaning subscales.

To address Research Question 1:
We will conduct a one way ANOVA with three conditions (self-reference writing prompt) predicting Authenticity (composite score). A significant main effect will be further tested with pairwise comparisons. We estimated our sample size based on this main effect, but also plan to explore individual differences further outlined in the exploratory analysis section.
To address Research Question 2:
We will conduct a repeated measures ANOVA (feedback type) predicting willingness to pay. A significant main effect will be further tested with pairwise comparisons. Additionally, we will consider possible confounds of the self-reference writing task. We will run a mixed ANOVA of Feedback Condition (4 levels within subjects) x Self-Reference Writing (3 levels between subjects) to test for interactive effects on willingness to pay.

q21.value: For the planned analyses, effects will be interpreted as significant if p(two-tailed) < .05.

q22.value: Responses that are more or less than 3 standard deviations from the mean will be excluded on a trial by trial basis. Additionally, participants who withdraw consent will be excluded entirely. In the case of computer failure, we will include a participant in relevant analyses if they have completed a full measure of the self-reference writing task and authenticity measure OR if they have completed the willingness to pay procedure for feedback value assessment.

registration_responses.q1: Feeling Authentic: What is the Source?
registration_responses.q3:
Research Question 1:
What makes us feel authentic? Theories of authenticity suggest that people should feel most authentic when they act in line with the unique pattern of qualities that make up their true self, that is, what makes them really them (Harter, 2002; Kernis & Goldman, 2006; Schmader & Sedikides, 2018). However, daily diary studies consistently find that people feel most authentic when their behavior conforms to a particular pattern of personality traits (e.g., high extraversion, high agreeableness, high conscientiousness, low neuroticism, and high openness) rather than acting in line with their own patterns of baseline traits (see Beer & Harris, 2019 for a review).  
Why would this pattern of personality traits make people feel more authentic than the pattern of qualities they claim characterizes their true self? One possibility is suggested by the way we judge authenticity in objects. Specifically, people tend to judge the authenticity of food or other objects based on their conformity to convention (Lehman, O’Connor, Kovacs & Newman, 2018). The pattern of qualities that tend to be associated with feelings of authenticity in daily diary studies tend to be those that are valued by the participants’ societies (most studies have been conducted in Western countries). Research has shown that we view people as less than fully human when they fail to conform to societal conventions (Fincher & Tetlock, 2016). Therefore, when it comes time to make a judgment about our own authenticity, we may use criteria that are closer to how we judge the authenticity of an object such as food. It may be that we draw on social conventions about how a person should act to evaluate our own authenticity.
Therefore, we will test the extent to which feelings of authenticity are increased by thinking about what it means to be a human (e.g., “What is it about you that makes you human”), the true self (e.g., “What is it about you that makes you who you really are?”), or a control condition in which self-evaluation is grounded in a day’s activity (e.g., “What kind of activities are you doing today?”).

Question 1: Does priming someone to think about their humanity (general category) vs. their true self (unique to them) affect feelings of authenticity?

Research Question 2:
How much do people value learning about their “true self” compared to other kinds of self-relevant information?  Research on authenticity asserts that people strive to know their true selves (Harter, 2002; Kernis & Goldman, 2006; Schmader & Sedikides, 2018). In addition to research on authenticity and self-assessment, there is a large literature discussing people’s interest in self-enhancement (Alicke & Sedikides, 2011; Sherman & Hartson, 2011) and self-verification (Swann, 1983, 1990). However, there is less empirical evidence concerning how much people relatively place value on learning about their true, core selves in relation to self-enhancing and self-verifying information. This research tests how much people value feedback about their true self compared to self-verifying (confirming what you already know) or self-enhancing (only revealing your strengths) feedback. Our previous research has suggested that participants, when asked in a between-subject design, tend to value feedback about their true self more than self-verifying feedback (and self-enhancing feedback falls in between). In this study, we use a within-subject design to understand more explicit representations of value across these feedback types. That is, when people are aware that these various types of feedback are available, do they self-report placing more value on feedback about their true selves than self-verifying feedback (with self-enhancing feedback’s value falling in between the two) or do they show a different pattern of value? Specifically, we will measure  willingness to pay (WTP) for personality information as a function of the framing of the feedback as 1) revealing the true, core self, 2) confirming their preexisting self-conceptions, 3) as only self-enhancing in nature, or 4) not specified (control condition in which no details about the feedback are specified).

Question 2: Does an individual’s willingness to pay for personality information differ as a function of the framing of the feedback they will receive?

Exploratory Research Questions:
Question 3: We plan to explore the effect of the writing prompt manipulation on subcomponents of authenticity (rather than an aggregate score). We will conduct a parallel analyses as those described under “statistical models” for the four subscales of our Authenticity measure (unbiased processing, relational orientation, awareness, and behavior)

Question 4: We will test for correlations between Authenticity, the four subscales of Authenticity (awareness, unbiased processing, behavior, and relational orientation), Self-esteem, Meaning in Life, each factor of the BFI (openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism), and willingness to pay.

Question 5: We plan to explore the effect of the writing prompt manipulation on our meaning in life measure (both subscales, presence and search; Schlegel, Hicks, King & Arndt, 2011).

Hypothesis 2: We hypothesize that there will be a main effect of feedback type on willingness to pay. attributes.title: Quantification of Anterior Cingulate Sulcal variability in behavioural variant Frontotemporal Dementia (bvFTD)

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: Quantification of Anterior Cingulate Sulcal variability in behavioural variant Frontotemporal Dementia (bvFTD)

other.value: Secondary outcome measures will assess (1.) the distribution of a double cingulate sulcation pattern observed in the right hemisphere and (2.) inter-hemispheric distribution in the above populations. Furthermore we aim to identify (3.) if the absence of PCS influences age at diagnosis in the bvFTD population, as judged by the age at which bvFTD participants underwent magnetic resonance imaging. Other clinical variables of interest will be reviewed.

sample.value: Group sample sizes were calculated using Fishers exact test with Bonferroni correction to allow for comparison of three participant groups. Data used to calculate sample sizes was obtained from similar study carried out in a schizophrenia population. In order to obtain significance a minimum of 114 subjects will be required in each of the three groups, alpha 0.05, power 0.8.

analyses.value: The distribution of PCS in left hemispheres of each of the three study groups. Analysis of inter-hemispheric distribution will be analysed using asymmetry indices. p-values will be reported for all analyses.

outliers.value: Exclusions will be made on the basis of poor image quality, which does not allow for accurate visualisation and classification of the PCS

dependent.value: T1 weighted Magnetic Resonance (MR) image data will be assessed in accordance with a binary variable; The presence/ absence of a paracingulate sulcus (PCS). The PCS will be measured using brain imaging software and classified in accordance with an adapted classification of paracingulate sulcation patterns. The PCS will be categorised as either “present” (≥20 mm) or “absent” (≤19 mm). Where discontinuous, a PCS will only be classified as present where a single sulcal element is ≥20 mm.

conditions.value: Three groups. 1. A patient group consisting of sporadic behavioural variant Frontotemporal Dementia (bvFTD) participants whom have undergone genetic screening and do not possess the three most common genes causing familial bvFTD; C9prf72, Progranulin and tau. 2. A control group consisting of healthy age and gender matched control subjects. 3. A comparative group consisting of age, gender and cognitve status (according to mini mental state examination, MMSE) matched Alzheimers Dementia (AD) subjects.

hypothesis.value: The primary outcome measure is the assessment of the distribution of a double cingulate sulcation pattern in the left hemisphere of subjects with behavioural variant Frontotemporal Dementia (bvFTD). Percentage frequencies of this sulcal pattern in bvFTD subjects will be compared with those of an Alzheimers Dementia (AD) and Healthy Control (HC) population. We hypothesise a reduced pattern of left anterior cingulate sulcation in bvFTD compared with that observed in a healthy controls and AD.

study_type_other.value: Any additional exploratory or post-hoc analyses carried out, will be presented under a “exploratory analysis” or “post-hoc analysis” subsection of the result section or in supplementary materials of the article.

registration_responses.hypothesis: The primary outcome measure is the assessment of the distribution of a double cingulate sulcation pattern in the left hemisphere of subjects with behavioural variant Frontotemporal Dementia (bvFTD). Percentage frequencies of this sulcal pattern in bvFTD subjects will be compared with those of an Alzheimers Dementia (AD) and Healthy Control (HC) population. We hypothesise a reduced pattern of left anterior cingulate sulcation in bvFTD compared with that observed in a healthy controls and AD.
registration_responses.study_type_other: Any additional exploratory or post-hoc analyses carried out, will be presented under a “exploratory analysis” or “post-hoc analysis” subsection of the result section or in supplementary materials of the article.

attributes.title: Third-Party Punishment Deservedness and Severity as Determinants of Signaled Trust Experiment B

q1.value: Third-Party Punishment Deservedness and Severity as Determinants of Signaled Trust Experiment B

q3.value:
Contrary to the view that third-party punishment is entirely altruistic, recent research suggests that punishers gain reputational benefits from the seemingly selfless act of punishing. This implies that third-party punishment constitutes a signaling mechanism, and that punishment carries key information about the punisher. Nevertheless, how the signal is determined has not been fully examined.   
The signaling function of punishing could depend on an essential component of third-party punishment, its proportionality. In this study, I will test how deservedness and severity, two fundamental constituents of proportionality, interact to determine the trustworthiness signaled by the punisher. However in this Experiment B, (as opposed to Experiment A) we will control for the undeserved-no punishment condition by exacting a tax on players.

q4.value:
The reputational benefits of third-party punishing (TPP) in an economic game vary according to the punishment’s proportionality. Specifically:
1. The trustworthiness signaled via TPP and measured with a Trust Game (TG) is affected by two levels of deservedness (undeserved vs deserved) and two levels of punishment severity (no punishment vs high punishment severity). However, unlike Experiment A, in this case, if an observer chooses not to punish (i.e. no punishment conditions), she/he still has to pay a tax of equal value to the cost of punishing. 
2. Individuals choose potential partner in a Trust Game based on the level of deservedness (undeserved vs deserved) of the punishment and the level of punishment severity (no punishment vs high punishment severity) of the punisher in a TPP.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subjects study with a 2x2 design with 2 levels for the deservedness factor (deserved and not deserved) and two levels for the severity factor (no punishment and high severity punishment).

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to each of the 4 conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The data is sitting in Qualtrics in its raw form and has not been accessed by anyone. Only I and William Jimenez-Leal have access to it. In Prolific we set a limit of 600 observations and correspondingly in Qualtrics there are 602 recorded responses but we still don't know how many of those are usable data points, what their distribution is or if there were any issues with the completion of the task. No more responses will be collected at this point.

question.value: Prolific platform, only adult individuals who are fluent in English

q14.value: An a priori power analysis (with a minimum detectable effect of 0.3, an alpha level of 0.05 and a 0.9 power aiming to reasonably reduce Type 2 errors) rendered a total sample size of N = 480.  Given the possibility of incomplete responses and possibility of timing out, we rounded to 600.

question.value:
The deservedness and severity levels were manipulated thusly:
Deserved: The sender did not share with the receiver in the TPP
Undeserved: The sender did share with the receiver in the TPP
High Severity: The observer incurred a cost to punish the sender in the TPP
No Severity: The observer did not punish the sender in the TPP but still incurred the same cost as in the high-severity condition in the form of a tax

The dependent variables are:
1. The amount of money entrusted to the Recipient in the Trust Game
2. The chosen partner in the posterior Partner Preference Question

I will make use of general linear models where main effects and interactions will be examined. In this analysis, the amount of money sent in the TG as well as the chosen partner will be compared by both deservedness and severity

q20.value:
Player 6 = Deserved, No Severity
Player 9 = Undeserved, No Severity
Player 12 = Deserved, High Severity
Player 15 = Undeserved, High Severity

q22.value:
If participants did not complete the task in its entirety their responses will be excluded. 
Respondents who took less than 4 mins or more than 45 mins to complete the task will be excluded.
